intro: Noccaea fendleri subsp. californica, commonly known as California rock pepper, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other economically important plants. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and poor soil conditions. Its small, yellow flowers are clustered in racemes, and it produces small, round, peppery fruits. The species is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves, which help reduce water loss in its native habitat.
